elements.content: In situ molecular transformation under hydrothermal conditions is a feasible method to introduce distinct organic ligands and suppress competitive reactions between different synthons. However, this strategy has not yet been explored for the preparation of polyoxometalate (POM)-encapsulated metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). In this work, we designed and prepared a new compound, [Co2(3,3′-bpy)­(3,5′-bpp)­(4,3′-bpy)]­(H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (4,3′-bpy = 4,3′-dipyridine, 3,5′-bpp = 3,5′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­pyridine, and 3,3′-bpy = 3,3′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl) dipyridine), via an in situ ligand synthesis route. The compound shows a novel POM-encapsulated MOF structure with two pairs of left- and right-handed double helixes. These left- and right-handed helical chains further lead to triangular and rhombus-like channels, respectively. Moreover, the as-synthesized title compound shows superior electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with a low overpotential and Tafel slope of 92 mV and 92.1 mV dec–1, respectively, under a current density of 10 cm–2. Also, the compound exhibits a high activity for the photocatalytic degradation of the dye rhodamine B. The excellent performance of the compound may be attributed to the synergistic effect between W and Co elements and the presence of encapsulated POMs. The title compound proves that it is possible to prepare multifunctional MOFs with POMs and transition metals showing HER activity and dye degradation activity.
elements.clean_text: In situ molecular transformation under hydrothermal conditions is a feasible method to introduce distinct organic ligands and suppress competitive reactions between different synthons. However, this strategy has not yet been explored for the preparation of polyoxometalate (POM)-encapsulated metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). In this work, we designed and prepared a new compound, [Co2(3,3'-bpy)(3,5'-bpp)(4,3'-bpy)](H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (4,3'-bpy = 4,3'-dipyridine, 3,5'-bpp = 3,5'-bis(pyrid-4-yl)pyridine, and 3,3'-bpy = 3,3'-bis(pyrid-4-yl) dipyridine), via an in situ ligand synthesis route. The compound shows a novel POM-encapsulated MOF structure with two pairs of left- and right-handed double helixes. These left- and right-handed helical chains further lead to triangular and rhombus-like channels, respectively. Moreover, the as-synthesized title compound shows superior electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with a low overpotential and Tafel slope of 92 mV and 92.1 mV dec-1, respectively, under a current density of 10 cm-2. Also, the compound exhibits a high activity for the photocatalytic degradation of the dye rhodamine B. The excellent performance of the compound may be attributed to the synergistic effect between W and Co elements and the presence of encapsulated POMs. The title compound proves that it is possible to prepare multifunctional MOFs with POMs and transition metals showing HER activity and dye degradation activity.

elements.content: An unprecedented polyoxometalate-encapsulated metal−organic framework was synthesized via in situ ligand molecular transformation, which shows high catalytic activity in hydrogen evolution and dye degradation.
elements.clean_text: An unprecedented polyoxometalate-encapsulated metal-organic framework was synthesized via in situ ligand molecular transformation, which shows high catalytic activity in hydrogen evolution and dye degradation.

elements.content: Crystalline materials with regular porous architectures have attracted intense attention due to their intriguing topological structures and various potential applications. As a new generation of porous crystalline materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which are constructed by transition-metal nodes and organic linkers, have become a frontier research field over the last 20 years. In this respect, polyoxometalates (POMs) represent a vast library of inorganic polyoxoanion clusters that are able to generate different POM-based MOFs. The unique properties of POMs with various sizes, shapes, and high negative charges could enable the POM-based MOFs to exhibit adjustable porous sizes. In addition, besides their structural advantages, POMs allow chemical and structural modifications at a molecular level and can carry out reversible, fast, and multistep electron-transfer reactions without changing their structures. Therefore, POM-encapsulated MOFs have emerged as a new family of multifunctional hybrids that includes two key research fields: MOFs and POMs. One of the first proposed applications of POM-encapsulated MOFs is in heterogeneous catalysis, and thus, recently, such materials have made significant contributions to fields such as photo- and electrocatalysis. Nevertheless, very few examples of POM-encapsulated MOFs have been reported because the assembly of such MOFs is still a significant synthetic challenge. Organic ligands are key synthons to obtain the desired MOF skeleton. Mixed-ligand MOFs have more advantages than single-ligand ones, as a high level of practical molecular design and the potential synergetic coordinated interactions of distinct ligands with metals result in novel POM-encapsulated MOFs. Previously reported mixed-ligand MOFs were synthesized by directly adding different ligands into the reaction media. However, due to strong competitive reactions between the different ligands, it is difficult to control the composition, nuclearity, and stereochemistry of the resultant structures. Recent studies have revealed that in situ molecular transformation under hydrothermal conditions is a feasible method to introduce distinct organic ligands and suppress competitive reactions between the different synthons. However, this strategy has not yet been explored for the preparation of POM-encapsulated MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystalline materials with regular porous architectures have attracted intense attention due to their intriguing topological structures and various potential applications. As a new generation of porous crystalline materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are constructed by transition-metal nodes and organic linkers, have become a frontier research field over the last 20 years. In this respect, polyoxometalates (POMs) represent a vast library of inorganic polyoxoanion clusters that are able to generate different POM-based MOFs. The unique properties of POMs with various sizes, shapes, and high negative charges could enable the POM-based MOFs to exhibit adjustable porous sizes. In addition, besides their structural advantages, POMs allow chemical and structural modifications at a molecular level and can carry out reversible, fast, and multistep electron-transfer reactions without changing their structures. Therefore, POM-encapsulated MOFs have emerged as a new family of multifunctional hybrids that includes two key research fields: MOFs and POMs. One of the first proposed applications of POM-encapsulated MOFs is in heterogeneous catalysis, and thus, recently, such materials have made significant contributions to fields such as photo- and electrocatalysis. Nevertheless, very few examples of POM-encapsulated MOFs have been reported because the assembly of such MOFs is still a significant synthetic challenge. Organic ligands are key synthons to obtain the desired MOF skeleton. Mixed-ligand MOFs have more advantages than single-ligand ones, as a high level of practical molecular design and the potential synergetic coordinated interactions of distinct ligands with metals result in novel POM-encapsulated MOFs. Previously reported mixed-ligand MOFs were synthesized by directly adding different ligands into the reaction media. However, due to strong competitive reactions between the different ligands, it is difficult to control the composition, nuclearity, and stereochemistry of the resultant structures. Recent studies have revealed that in situ molecular transformation under hydrothermal conditions is a feasible method to introduce distinct organic ligands and suppress competitive reactions between the different synthons. However, this strategy has not yet been explored for the preparation of POM-encapsulated MOFs.

elements.content: In this work, a novel POM-encapsulated MOF compound, [Co2­(3,3′-bpy)­(3,5-bpp)­(4,3′-bpy)]­(H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (3,3′-bpy = 3,3′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­bipyridine, 3,5-bpp = 3,5′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­pyridine, and 4,3′-bpy = 4,3′-bipyridine), was obtained using an in situ molecular transformation route under hydrothermal conditions. Structural studies reveal that a part of the 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy in a self-assembly process. Because it is challenging to capture the reaction intermediates, a proposed mechanism for the in situ formation of 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy is deduced based on the analyses of the products and of the hydrothermal conditions as well as the related literature. Thus, the electron-withdrawing group on each pyridine ring facilitates a homolytic break of the C–C single bonds of 3,5-bbp to form two active radicals, namely, 3,4-bipyridine and pyridine free radicals. Subsequently, the new ligand 4,3′-bpy is formed by the rearrangement and reaction of two pyridine free radicals, whereas 3,3′-bpy is formed by the reaction of two 3,4-bipyridine free radicals (). The as-synthesized 1 shows high electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with an overpotential of 92 mV at 10 cm–2and a Tafel slope of 92.1 mV dec–1. The outstanding HER activity of the POM-encapsulated MOF may benefit from the synergistic cooperation between Co and W of the active structures and a high specific surface area. Furthermore, compound 1 shows a superior activity for the catalytic degradation of rhodamine B (Rh-B) under UV irradiation. Both results demonstrate that it is possible to prepare mixed-ligand POM-encapsulated MOFs with different practical applications.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a novel POM-encapsulated MOF compound, [Co2(3,3'-bpy)(3,5-bpp)(4,3'-bpy)](H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (3,3'-bpy = 3,3'-bis(pyrid-4-yl)bipyridine, 3,5-bpp = 3,5'-bis(pyrid-4-yl)pyridine, and 4,3'-bpy = 4,3'-bipyridine), was obtained using an in situ molecular transformation route under hydrothermal conditions. Structural studies reveal that a part of the 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy in a self-assembly process. Because it is challenging to capture the reaction intermediates, a proposed mechanism for the in situ formation of 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy is deduced based on the analyses of the products and of the hydrothermal conditions as well as the related literature. Thus, the electron-withdrawing group on each pyridine ring facilitates a homolytic break of the C-C single bonds of 3,5-bbp to form two active radicals, namely, 3,4-bipyridine and pyridine free radicals. Subsequently, the new ligand 4,3'-bpy is formed by the rearrangement and reaction of two pyridine free radicals, whereas 3,3'-bpy is formed by the reaction of two 3,4-bipyridine free radicals (). The as-synthesized 1 shows high electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with an overpotential of 92 mV at 10 cm-2and a Tafel slope of 92.1 mV dec-1. The outstanding HER activity of the POM-encapsulated MOF may benefit from the synergistic cooperation between Co and W of the active structures and a high specific surface area. Furthermore, compound 1 shows a superior activity for the catalytic degradation of rhodamine B (Rh-B) under UV irradiation. Both results demonstrate that it is possible to prepare mixed-ligand POM-encapsulated MOFs with different practical applications.

elements.clean_text: 1  Possible Molecular Transformation Process of 3,5-bpp into 3,3'-bpy and 4,3'-bpy

elements.content: The synthesis of compound 1 and some additional experiments are described in the Supporting Information (SI). To confirm the purity of 3,5-bbp, 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of 3,5-bbp were analyzed. These spectra are as follows: 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 9.12 (s, 2H, pyHc), 8.73 (d, 4H, pyHb), 8.61 (s, 1H, pyHd), 7.96 (d, 4H, pyHa) (Figure S6). 13C NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 150.4 (Cb), 148.3 (Cc), 143.8 (Cf), 133.1 (Cb3), 132.8 (Cd), 121.7 (Ca) (Figure S7). In Figures S6 and S7, except for the assigned peaks, there are scarcely any other main peaks, which proves that the purity of the 3,5-bbp ligand is good. That is, 3,3′-bpy and 4,3′-bpy are not formed from the impurity of 3,5-bpp. The result further proved that 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy in a self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The synthesis of compound 1 and some additional experiments are described in the Supporting Information (SI). To confirm the purity of 3,5-bbp, 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of 3,5-bbp were analyzed. These spectra are as follows: 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 9.12 (s, 2H, pyHc), 8.73 (d, 4H, pyHb), 8.61 (s, 1H, pyHd), 7.96 (d, 4H, pyHa) (Figure S6). 13C NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 150.4 (Cb), 148.3 (Cc), 143.8 (Cf), 133.1 (Cb3), 132.8 (Cd), 121.7 (Ca) (Figure S7). In Figures S6 and S7, except for the assigned peaks, there are scarcely any other main peaks, which proves that the purity of the 3,5-bbp ligand is good. That is, 3,3'-bpy and 4,3'-bpy are not formed from the impurity of 3,5-bpp. The result further proved that 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy in a self-assembly process.

elements.content: Compound 1 was crystallized in the rhombohedral space group Pna21, as shown in Table S1. A structural analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Keggin-type SiW12O40 4– (SiW12) cluster, two crystallographically independent Co ions (Co1 and Co2), three distinct organic ligands (3,3′-bpy, 3,5-bpp, and 4,3′-bpy), and six coordinated water molecules (). Co1 and Co2 show an identical six-coordinated mode, but they possess different coordination environments (Figure S2). Co1 is connected to four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N4, and N9) from two 4,3′-bpy and two 3,3′-bpy molecules and two oxygen atoms, respectively, from one terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion (O21) and one water molecule. The Co2 is linked to three nitrogen atoms (N6, N7, and N8) from one 3,5-bpp and two 4,3′-bpy molecules and to three oxygen atoms from a terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion and two water molecules, respectively. The Co–N and Co–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.07(2)–2.18(14) Å and 2.12(13)–2.19 (14) Å, respectively, which are in the normal range. The POM-based three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 is built from the in situ-created new ligands that exhibit different coordination modes. The simultaneous presence of 3,5-bpp, together with the in situ-formed 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy ligands, generates a 3D (3,5)-connected open framework with a (3674) (3272) topology (Figure S5). The 3,3′-bpy ligand exhibits two configurations (Figure S3) to connect Co1 with Co2. The 3,5-bpp ligand favors the formation of a helicoidal structure because it is a linked heterocyclic ligand with three nitrogen donor atoms. The Keggin SiW12 clusters act as charge-compensating guests and as bridges connecting Co1 and Co2 ions through two edge-sharing WO6 octahedra (Figure S1), but they are not necessary for the construction of this 3D framework. The overall cationic coordination network of 1 contains two subunits: a triangular and a rhombus-like channel ().
elements.clean_text:
Structure and Characterization of the Crystal Structure

Compound 1 was crystallized in the rhombohedral space group Pna21, as shown in Table S1. A structural analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Keggin-type SiW12O40 4- (SiW12) cluster, two crystallographically independent Co ions (Co1 and Co2), three distinct organic ligands (3,3'-bpy, 3,5-bpp, and 4,3'-bpy), and six coordinated water molecules (). Co1 and Co2 show an identical six-coordinated mode, but they possess different coordination environments (Figure S2). Co1 is connected to four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N4, and N9) from two 4,3'-bpy and two 3,3'-bpy molecules and two oxygen atoms, respectively, from one terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion (O21) and one water molecule. The Co2 is linked to three nitrogen atoms (N6, N7, and N8) from one 3,5-bpp and two 4,3'-bpy molecules and to three oxygen atoms from a terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion and two water molecules, respectively. The Co-N and Co-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.07(2)-2.18(14) Å and 2.12(13)-2.19 (14) Å, respectively, which are in the normal range. The POM-based three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 is built from the in situ-created new ligands that exhibit different coordination modes. The simultaneous presence of 3,5-bpp, together with the in situ-formed 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy ligands, generates a 3D (3,5)-connected open framework with a (3674) (3272) topology (Figure S5). The 3,3'-bpy ligand exhibits two configurations (Figure S3) to connect Co1 with Co2. The 3,5-bpp ligand favors the formation of a helicoidal structure because it is a linked heterocyclic ligand with three nitrogen donor atoms. The Keggin SiW12 clusters act as charge-compensating guests and as bridges connecting Co1 and Co2 ions through two edge-sharing WO6 octahedra (Figure S1), but they are not necessary for the construction of this 3D framework. The overall cationic coordination network of 1 contains two subunits: a triangular and a rhombus-like channel ().

elements.content: Left- and right-handed helical chains give rise to (a) triangular and (b) rhombus-like channels along the [001] direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  Left- and right-handed helical chains give rise to (a) triangular and (b) rhombus-like channels along the [001] direction.

elements.content: The triangular channels are formed by cobalt ions linked to one 3,3′-bpy and two 4,3′-bpy bridging ligands to generate helical chains (A-type) with the formula Co3[(3,3′-bpy)­(4,3′-bpy)2], with a step of 30 atoms and an almost isosceles triangular shape with dimensions of 13.96 × 9.78 × 9.86 Å3 (Figure S4). The pitch of helical chains is ca. 19.88 Å. Each Co3[(3,3′-bpy)­(4,3′-bpy)2] A-type helical chain is connected, through 3,5-bpp ligands, to another A-type chain with an inverse helicity to form two left- and right-handed helixes running along the [001] direction, which give rise to the triangular channels depicted in a. The rhombus-like channels are formed by cobalt ions connected to two 4,3′-bpy and two 3,3′-bpy bridging ligands to generate helical chains (B-type) with the formula Co4[(3,3′-bpy)2(4,3′-bpy)2], with a step of 40 atoms and a rhombus-like shape with dimensions of 13.96 × 9.86 Å2 (Figure S4). The pitch of helical chains is ca. 18.83 Å. This B-type Co4[(3,3′-bpy)2(4,3′-bpy)2] helical chain is connected to another B-type chain with inverse helicity through 3,5-bpp ligands to form helixes running along the [001] direction, giving rise to triangular and rhombus-like channels (b).
elements.clean_text: The triangular channels are formed by cobalt ions linked to one 3,3'-bpy and two 4,3'-bpy bridging ligands to generate helical chains (A-type) with the formula Co3[(3,3'-bpy)(4,3'-bpy)2], with a step of 30 atoms and an almost isosceles triangular shape with dimensions of 13.96 × 9.78 × 9.86 Å3 (Figure S4). The pitch of helical chains is ca. 19.88 Å. Each Co3[(3,3'-bpy)(4,3'-bpy)2] A-type helical chain is connected, through 3,5-bpp ligands, to another A-type chain with an inverse helicity to form two left- and right-handed helixes running along the [001] direction, which give rise to the triangular channels depicted in a. The rhombus-like channels are formed by cobalt ions connected to two 4,3'-bpy and two 3,3'-bpy bridging ligands to generate helical chains (B-type) with the formula Co4[(3,3'-bpy)2(4,3'-bpy)2], with a step of 40 atoms and a rhombus-like shape with dimensions of 13.96 × 9.86 Å2 (Figure S4). The pitch of helical chains is ca. 18.83 Å. This B-type Co4[(3,3'-bpy)2(4,3'-bpy)2] helical chain is connected to another B-type chain with inverse helicity through 3,5-bpp ligands to form helixes running along the [001] direction, giving rise to triangular and rhombus-like channels (b).

elements.content: The structure of 1 is built up by edge-sharing triangular (A-type) and rhombus-like (B-type) channels (). The larger rhombus-like channels encapsulate the Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4– anions as charge-compensating guests. Intriguingly, after the inclusion of the SiW12 clusters, the final MOF still has an apparent void space. The effective free volume calculated by PLATON is 1470.7 Å3 after the elimination of free water molecules, corresponding to 18.6% of the whole crystal volume (7897.8 Å3).
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 is built up by edge-sharing triangular (A-type) and rhombus-like (B-type) channels (). The larger rhombus-like channels encapsulate the Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4- anions as charge-compensating guests. Intriguingly, after the inclusion of the SiW12 clusters, the final MOF still has an apparent void space. The effective free volume calculated by PLATON is 1470.7 Å3 after the elimination of free water molecules, corresponding to 18.6% of the whole crystal volume (7897.8 Å3).

elements.content: 3D POM-encapsulated MOF architecture.
elements.clean_text: 2  3D POM-encapsulated MOF architecture.

elements.content: The morphology and structure of 1 were characterized by several methods. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image shows that 1 crystallizes as regular polyhedral crystals with typical dimensions of ca. 500 × 250 × 150 μm3 (Figure S8). The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurement demonstrates that it contains C, O, N, Co, Si, and W (Figure S9) and that all of the elements are uniformly distributed (Figure S10). To further confirm the structure of 1, Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were also conducted. The results of XPS, FTIR, PXRD, and TG tests were also consistent with the results of the above structural analyses (Figures S11–S14). The semiconductor behavior and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) area are good indicators of potential catalytic activity, and therefore, we measured the band gap and BET area of 1 (Figure S15). The bandgap value (2.17 eV) and the BET surface area (7.8 m2 g–1) suggest that compound 1 may have abundant ion/electron active sites for electron transfer.
elements.clean_text: The morphology and structure of 1 were characterized by several methods. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image shows that 1 crystallizes as regular polyhedral crystals with typical dimensions of ca. 500 × 250 × 150 μm3 (Figure S8). The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurement demonstrates that it contains C, O, N, Co, Si, and W (Figure S9) and that all of the elements are uniformly distributed (Figure S10). To further confirm the structure of 1, Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were also conducted. The results of XPS, FTIR, PXRD, and TG tests were also consistent with the results of the above structural analyses (Figures S11-S14). The semiconductor behavior and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) area are good indicators of potential catalytic activity, and therefore, we measured the band gap and BET area of 1 (Figure S15). The bandgap value (2.17 eV) and the BET surface area (7.8 m2 g-1) suggest that compound 1 may have abundant ion/electron active sites for electron transfer.

elements.content: To explore the electrocatalytic performance of compound 1, we tested the electrocatalytic activity of 1-doped composites with different contents, measured under the same conditions, using a classical three-electrode method in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution using nickel foam (NF) and 20 wt % Pt/C (commercial)-loaded nickel foam. All obtained potentials were calibrated against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). a shows the polarization curves of the electrodes at 5 mV s–1 at the given voltage. The overpotentials of the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites are 129, 92, and 189 mV (current density 10 mA cm–2), respectively. These results show that the HER activities of compound 1-doped electrodes are enhanced when a certain amount of carbon black is present. The composite having 50 wt % of compound 1 exhibits the best catalytic behavior for HER. This behavior can be attributed not only to the improvement of the electrical conductivity due to the presence of carbon black doped into the electrodes but also to the electron interactions between the POM-encapsulated MOF catalysts and the Ni foam electrodes.
elements.clean_text:
Electrocatalytic HER Measurements

To explore the electrocatalytic performance of compound 1, we tested the electrocatalytic activity of 1-doped composites with different contents, measured under the same conditions, using a classical three-electrode method in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution using nickel foam (NF) and 20 wt % Pt/C (commercial)-loaded nickel foam. All obtained potentials were calibrated against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). a shows the polarization curves of the electrodes at 5 mV s-1 at the given voltage. The overpotentials of the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites are 129, 92, and 189 mV (current density 10 mA cm-2), respectively. These results show that the HER activities of compound 1-doped electrodes are enhanced when a certain amount of carbon black is present. The composite having 50 wt % of compound 1 exhibits the best catalytic behavior for HER. This behavior can be attributed not only to the improvement of the electrical conductivity due to the presence of carbon black doped into the electrodes but also to the electron interactions between the POM-encapsulated MOF catalysts and the Ni foam electrodes.

elements.content: Electrochemical performance of compound 1-doped composites with different contents: (a) linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves in 1 mol/L KOH. (b) Tafel plots. (c) I–time curve of the compound 1-doped composite with 50% content at 10 mA cm–2 for 48 h. (d) Electrocatalytic schematic mechanism of compound 1 for HER.
elements.clean_text: 3  Electrochemical performance of compound 1-doped composites with different contents: (a) linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves in 1 mol/L KOH. (b) Tafel plots. (c) I-time curve of the compound 1-doped composite with 50% content at 10 mA cm-2 for 48 h. (d) Electrocatalytic schematic mechanism of compound 1 for HER.

elements.content: To investigate the HER kinetics of the electrocatalysts, the Tafel slope tests were evaluated through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). As shown in b, the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites showed Tafel slopes of 118.6, 92.1, and 119.7 mV dec–1, respectively. These values are higher than that of Pt/C (34 mV dec–1) but lower than that of NF (161.7 mV dec–1). The 50% composite exhibits the lowest Tafel slope among the three composites, indicating the fastest kinetics for HER. As can be seen in Table S2, the catalytic performance of our composites for HER is better than that of most of the reported values for similar MOFs and POMOFs. Because, in general, the electrocatalytic performance relates to the conductivity and structure of the catalysts, we can attribute the excellent catalytic performance of the composites to both features. Compound 1 contains Keggin [SiW12O40]4– POMs with a high negative charge encapsulated into a 3D porous framework, leading to many active sites to absorb the reaction intermediates. In addition, the cooperation of the active centers (Co and W) present in the structure of compound 1 may improve the kinetics of HER. The durability tests of compound 1, conducted at 10 mA cm–2, show almost no current deactivation for 48 h (c). This result proves that compound 1 possesses excellent durability for HER. In alkaline environments, the electrocatalytic HER takes place through three steps at the surface of the electrodes (active sites), including electron transfer and/or hydrogen desorption. These steps are as follows: (1) The Volmer step, i.e., the electrochemical adsorption of hydrogen intermediates (Had) on the surface of the catalysts: H2O + e– + Medges 0 → Hads@Medges 0 + OH–. (2) The Heyrovsky step, where two hydrogen intermediates (Had) combine to form molecular hydrogen (H2), followed by desorption: 2Hads@Medges 0 + H2O + e– → H2 + OH– + Medges 0. (3) The Tafel route, which is related to the direct combination of two absorbed H atoms: 2Hads@Medges 0 → H2. The composites studied in this work most probably show the Volmer–Heyrovsky mechanism for HER, as shown in d.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the HER kinetics of the electrocatalysts, the Tafel slope tests were evaluated through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). As shown in b, the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites showed Tafel slopes of 118.6, 92.1, and 119.7 mV dec-1, respectively. These values are higher than that of Pt/C (34 mV dec-1) but lower than that of NF (161.7 mV dec-1). The 50% composite exhibits the lowest Tafel slope among the three composites, indicating the fastest kinetics for HER. As can be seen in Table S2, the catalytic performance of our composites for HER is better than that of most of the reported values for similar MOFs and POMOFs. Because, in general, the electrocatalytic performance relates to the conductivity and structure of the catalysts, we can attribute the excellent catalytic performance of the composites to both features. In addition, the cooperation of the active centers (Co and W) present in the structure of compound 1 may improve the kinetics of HER. The durability tests of compound 1, conducted at 10 mA cm-2, show almost no current deactivation for 48 h (c). This result proves that compound 1 possesses excellent durability for HER. In alkaline environments, the electrocatalytic HER takes place through three steps at the surface of the electrodes (active sites), including electron transfer and/or hydrogen desorption. These steps are as follows: (1) The Volmer step, i.e., the electrochemical adsorption of hydrogen intermediates (Had) on the surface of the catalysts: H2O + e- + Medges 0 → Hads@Medges 0 + OH-. (2) The Heyrovsky step, where two hydrogen intermediates (Had) combine to form molecular hydrogen (H2), followed by desorption: 2Hads@Medges 0 + H2O + e- → H2 + OH- + Medges 0. (3) The Tafel route, which is related to the direct combination of two absorbed H atoms: 2Hads@Medges 0 → H2. The composites studied in this work most probably show the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for HER, as shown in d.

elements.content: Besides the HER activity, using compound 1 as a photocatalyst in photocatalytic experiments shows that the absorption intensity of aqueous rhodamine B (RhB) sharply decreases within 2 h under UV light irradiation (a). The C 0 – C/C 0 vs reaction time plots (c) demonstrate that approximately 92% of the dye was decomposed after 120 min in the presence of compound 1 in contrast to less than 12% when no photocatalyst was added (b,c). These results suggest that compound 1 has good catalytic activity and possesses the potential for application in the photocatalytic degradation of dyes polluting water. The photocatalytic experiment was repeated three times with the same sample with no apparent reduction of the degradation rate in the photocatalytic tests (d). Therefore, compound 1 can be recycled and reused as a photocatalyst. The proposed photocatalytic mechanism of compound 1 is shown in Figure S16. The stability of compound 1 after the photocatalysis cycles is further confirmed by PXRD, which shows no apparent changes in the diffractograms of compound 1 after three cycles (Figure S17) and is similar to the simulated results. The slight differences in the peak intensity are due to the different orientations of the crystals in the sample. This result indicates that the stability of the 1-based photocatalyst is good.

The photocatalytic experiment was repeated three times with the same sample with no apparent reduction of the degradation rate in the photocatalytic tests (d). Therefore, compound 1 can be recycled and reused as a photocatalyst. The proposed photocatalytic mechanism of compound 1 is shown in Figure S16. The stability of compound 1 after the photocatalysis cycles is further confirmed by PXRD, which shows no apparent changes in the diffractograms of compound 1 after three cycles (Figure S17) and is similar to the simulated results. The slight differences in the peak intensity are due to the different orientations of the crystals in the sample. This result indicates that the stability of the 1-based photocatalyst is good.

elements.content: UV spectra of the RhB solution (a) with catalyst 1 and (b) without the catalyst. (c) Degradation rate of RhB vs the reaction time. (d) Recycling experiments.
elements.clean_text: 4  UV spectra of the RhB solution (a) with catalyst 1 and (b) without the catalyst. (c) Degradation rate of RhB vs the reaction time. (d) Recycling experiments.

elements.content: In summary, we prepared a new 3D porous POM-based MOF with in situ organic ligands and Co­(II) ions. The structure of this MOF has channels with encapsulated POMs, which constitute rich active sites for the electrochemical HER. Thus, the compound 1-based catalyst exhibits a high electrocatalytic activity to generate H2 through water splitting in an alkaline solution, with a low overpotential of 92 mV (current density 10 mA cm–2) and high stability for not less than 48 h. In addition, compound 1 exhibits an outstanding photocatalytic performance for degrading RhB under the irradiation of UV light. The excellent performance of compound 1 could be attributed to the synergistic effect between W and Co elements and the presence of encapsulated POMs. Compound 1 proves that it is possible to prepare multifunctional MOFs with POMs and transition metals showing HER activity and dye degradation activity.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we prepared a new 3D porous POM-based MOF with in situ organic ligands and Co(II) ions. The structure of this MOF has channels with encapsulated POMs, which constitute rich active sites for the electrochemical HER. Thus, the compound 1-based catalyst exhibits a high electrocatalytic activity to generate H2 through water splitting in an alkaline solution, with a low overpotential of 92 mV (current density 10 mA cm-2) and high stability for not less than 48 h. In addition, compound 1 exhibits an outstanding photocatalytic performance for degrading RhB under the irradiation of UV light. The excellent performance of compound 1 could be attributed to the synergistic effect between W and Co elements and the presence of encapsulated POMs. Compound 1 proves that it is possible to prepare multifunctional MOFs with POMs and transition metals showing HER activity and dye degradation activity.

cln_elements.content: In this work, a novel POM-encapsulated MOF compound, [Co2­(3,3′-bpy)­(3,5-bpp)­(4,3′-bpy)]­(H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (3,3′-bpy = 3,3′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­bipyridine, 3,5-bpp = 3,5′-bis­(pyrid-4-yl)­pyridine, and 4,3′-bpy = 4,3′-bipyridine), was obtained using an in situ molecular transformation route under hydrothermal conditions. Structural studies reveal that a part of the 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy in a self-assembly process. Because it is challenging to capture the reaction intermediates, a proposed mechanism for the in situ formation of 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy is deduced based on the analyses of the products and of the hydrothermal conditions as well as the related literature. Thus, the electron-withdrawing group on each pyridine ring facilitates a homolytic break of the C–C single bonds of 3,5-bbp to form two active radicals, namely, 3,4-bipyridine and pyridine free radicals. Subsequently, the new ligand 4,3′-bpy is formed by the rearrangement and reaction of two pyridine free radicals, whereas 3,3′-bpy is formed by the reaction of two 3,4-bipyridine free radicals (). The as-synthesized 1 shows high electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with an overpotential of 92 mV at 10 cm–2and a Tafel slope of 92.1 mV dec–1. The outstanding HER activity of the POM-encapsulated MOF may benefit from the synergistic cooperation between Co and W of the active structures and a high specific surface area. Furthermore, compound 1 shows a superior activity for the catalytic degradation of rhodamine B (Rh-B) under UV irradiation. Both results demonstrate that it is possible to prepare mixed-ligand POM-encapsulated MOFs with different practical applications.
cln_elements.clean_text: In this work, a novel POM-encapsulated MOF compound, [Co2(3,3'-bpy)(3,5-bpp)(4,3'-bpy)](H2O)3[SiW12O40] (1) (3,3'-bpy = 3,3'-bis(pyrid-4-yl)bipyridine, 3,5-bpp = 3,5'-bis(pyrid-4-yl)pyridine, and 4,3'-bpy = 4,3'-bipyridine), was obtained using an in situ molecular transformation route under hydrothermal conditions. Structural studies reveal that a part of the 3,5-bbp ligands underwent rearrangement reactions and transformed into the ligands 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy in a self-assembly process. Because it is challenging to capture the reaction intermediates, a proposed mechanism for the in situ formation of 4,3'-bpy and 3,3'-bpy is deduced based on the analyses of the products and of the hydrothermal conditions as well as the related literature. Thus, the electron-withdrawing group on each pyridine ring facilitates a homolytic break of the C-C single bonds of 3,5-bbp to form two active radicals, namely, 3,4-bipyridine and pyridine free radicals. Subsequently, the new ligand 4,3'-bpy is formed by the rearrangement and reaction of two pyridine free radicals, whereas 3,3'-bpy is formed by the reaction of two 3,4-bipyridine free radicals (). The as-synthesized 1 shows high electrocatalytic activity toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in 1 M KOH aqueous solution with an overpotential of 92 mV at 10 cm-2and a Tafel slope of 92.1 mV dec-1. The outstanding HER activity of the POM-encapsulated MOF may benefit from the synergistic cooperation between Co and W of the active structures and a high specific surface area. Furthermore, compound 1 shows a superior activity for the catalytic degradation of rhodamine B (Rh-B) under UV irradiation. Both results demonstrate that it is possible to prepare mixed-ligand POM-encapsulated MOFs with different practical applications.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was crystallized in the rhombohedral space group Pna21, as shown in Table S1. A structural analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Keggin-type SiW12O40 4– (SiW12) cluster, two crystallographically independent Co ions (Co1 and Co2), three distinct organic ligands (3,3′-bpy, 3,5-bpp, and 4,3′-bpy), and six coordinated water molecules (). Co1 and Co2 show an identical six-coordinated mode, but they possess different coordination environments (Figure S2). Co1 is connected to four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N4, and N9) from two 4,3′-bpy and two 3,3′-bpy molecules and two oxygen atoms, respectively, from one terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion (O21) and one water molecule. The Co2 is linked to three nitrogen atoms (N6, N7, and N8) from one 3,5-bpp and two 4,3′-bpy molecules and to three oxygen atoms from a terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion and two water molecules, respectively. The Co–N and Co–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.07(2)–2.18(14) Å and 2.12(13)–2.19 (14) Å, respectively, which are in the normal range. The POM-based three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 is built from the in situ-created new ligands that exhibit different coordination modes. The simultaneous presence of 3,5-bpp, together with the in situ-formed 4,3′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy ligands, generates a 3D (3,5)-connected open framework with a (3674) (3272) topology (Figure S5). The 3,3′-bpy ligand exhibits two configurations (Figure S3) to connect Co1 with Co2. The 3,5-bpp ligand favors the formation of a helicoidal structure because it is a linked heterocyclic ligand with three nitrogen donor atoms. The Keggin SiW12 clusters act as charge-compensating guests and as bridges connecting Co1 and Co2 ions through two edge-sharing WO6 octahedra (Figure S1), but they are not necessary for the construction of this 3D framework. The overall cationic coordination network of 1 contains two subunits: a triangular and a rhombus-like channel ().

The structure of 1 is built up by edge-sharing triangular (A-type) and rhombus-like (B-type) channels (). The larger rhombus-like channels encapsulate the Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4– anions as charge-compensating guests. Intriguingly, after the inclusion of the SiW12 clusters, the final MOF still has an apparent void space. The effective free volume calculated by PLATON is 1470.7 Å3 after the elimination of free water molecules, corresponding to 18.6% of the whole crystal volume (7897.8 Å3).

The morphology and structure of 1 were characterized by several methods. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image shows that 1 crystallizes as regular polyhedral crystals with typical dimensions of ca. 500 × 250 × 150 μm3 (Figure S8). The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurement demonstrates that it contains C, O, N, Co, Si, and W (Figure S9) and that all of the elements are uniformly distributed (Figure S10). To further confirm the structure of 1, Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies were also conducted. The results of XPS, FTIR, PXRD, and TG tests were also consistent with the results of the above structural analyses (Figures S11–S14). The semiconductor behavior and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) area are good indicators of potential catalytic activity, and therefore, we measured the band gap and BET area of 1 (Figure S15). The bandgap value (2.17 eV) and the BET surface area (7.8 m2 g–1) suggest that compound 1 may have abundant ion/electron active sites for electron transfer.

Electrocatalytic HER Measurements

To explore the electrocatalytic performance of compound 1, we tested the electrocatalytic activity of 1-doped composites with different contents, measured under the same conditions, using a classical three-electrode method in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution using nickel foam (NF) and 20 wt % Pt/C (commercial)-loaded nickel foam. All obtained potentials were calibrated against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). a shows the polarization curves of the electrodes at 5 mV s–1 at the given voltage. The overpotentials of the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites are 129, 92, and 189 mV (current density 10 mA cm–2), respectively. These results show that the HER activities of compound 1-doped electrodes are enhanced when a certain amount of carbon black is present. The composite having 50 wt % of compound 1 exhibits the best catalytic behavior for HER. This behavior can be attributed not only to the improvement of the electrical conductivity due to the presence of carbon black doped into the electrodes but also to the electron interactions between the POM-encapsulated MOF catalysts and the Ni foam electrodes.

To investigate the HER kinetics of the electrocatalysts, the Tafel slope tests were evaluated through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). As shown in b, the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites showed Tafel slopes of 118.6, 92.1, and 119.7 mV dec–1, respectively. These values are higher than that of Pt/C (34 mV dec–1) but lower than that of NF (161.7 mV dec–1). The 50% composite exhibits the lowest Tafel slope among the three composites, indicating the fastest kinetics for HER. As can be seen in Table S2, the catalytic performance of our composites for HER is better than that of most of the reported values for similar MOFs and POMOFs. Because, in general, the electrocatalytic performance relates to the conductivity and structure of the catalysts, we can attribute the excellent catalytic performance of the composites to both features. Compound 1 contains Keggin [SiW12O40]4– POMs with a high negative charge encapsulated into a 3D porous framework, leading to many active sites to absorb the reaction intermediates. In addition, the cooperation of the active centers (Co and W) present in the structure of compound 1 may improve the kinetics of HER. The durability tests of compound 1, conducted at 10 mA cm–2, show almost no current deactivation for 48 h (c). This result proves that compound 1 possesses excellent durability for HER. In alkaline environments, the electrocatalytic HER takes place through three steps at the surface of the electrodes (active sites), including electron transfer and/or hydrogen desorption. These steps are as follows: (1) The Volmer step, i.e., the electrochemical adsorption of hydrogen intermediates (Had) on the surface of the catalysts: H2O + e– + Medges 0 → Hads@Medges 0 + OH–. (2) The Heyrovsky step, where two hydrogen intermediates (Had) combine to form molecular hydrogen (H2), followed by desorption: 2Hads@Medges 0 + H2O + e– → H2 + OH– + Medges 0. (3) The Tafel route, which is related to the direct combination of two absorbed H atoms: 2Hads@Medges 0 → H2. The composites studied in this work most probably show the Volmer–Heyrovsky mechanism for HER, as shown in d.

Besides the HER activity, using compound 1 as a photocatalyst in photocatalytic experiments shows that the absorption intensity of aqueous rhodamine B (RhB) sharply decreases within 2 h under UV light irradiation (a). The C 0 – C/C 0 vs reaction time plots (c) demonstrate that approximately 92% of the dye was decomposed after 120 min in the presence of compound 1 in contrast to less than 12% when no photocatalyst was added (b,c). These results suggest that compound 1 has good catalytic activity and possesses the potential for application in the photocatalytic degradation of dyes polluting water. The photocatalytic experiment was repeated three times with the same sample with no apparent reduction of the degradation rate in the photocatalytic tests (d). Therefore, compound 1 can be recycled and reused as a photocatalyst. The proposed photocatalytic mechanism of compound 1 is shown in Figure S16. The stability of compound 1 after the photocatalysis cycles is further confirmed by PXRD, which shows no apparent changes in the diffractograms of compound 1 after three cycles (Figure S17) and is similar to the simulated results. The slight differences in the peak intensity are due to the different orientations of the crystals in the sample. This result indicates that the stability of the 1-based photocatalyst is good.

In summary, we prepared a new 3D porous POM-based MOF with in situ organic ligands and Co­(II) ions. The structure of this MOF has channels with encapsulated POMs, which constitute rich active sites for the electrochemical HER. Thus, the compound 1-based catalyst exhibits a high electrocatalytic activity to generate H2 through water splitting in an alkaline solution, with a low overpotential of 92 mV (current density 10 mA cm–2) and high stability for not less than 48 h. In addition, compound 1 exhibits an outstanding photocatalytic performance for degrading RhB under the irradiation of UV light. The excellent performance of compound 1 could be attributed to the synergistic effect between W and Co elements and the presence of encapsulated POMs. Compound 1 proves that it is possible to prepare multifunctional MOFs with POMs and transition metals showing HER activity and dye degradation activity.

Structure and Characterization of the Crystal Structure

Compound 1 was crystallized in the rhombohedral space group Pna21, as shown in Table S1. A structural analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of a Keggin-type SiW12O40 4- (SiW12) cluster, two crystallographically independent Co ions (Co1 and Co2), three distinct organic ligands (3,3'-bpy, 3,5-bpp, and 4,3'-bpy), and six coordinated water molecules (). Co1 and Co2 show an identical six-coordinated mode, but they possess different coordination environments (Figure S2). The Co2 is linked to three nitrogen atoms (N6, N7, and N8) from one 3,5-bpp and two 4,3'-bpy molecules and to three oxygen atoms from a terminal oxygen of a SiW12 anion and two water molecules, respectively. To explore the electrocatalytic performance of compound 1, we tested the electrocatalytic activity of 1-doped composites with different contents, measured under the same conditions, using a classical three-electrode method in 1.0 mol/L KOH solution using nickel foam (NF) and 20 wt % Pt/C (commercial)-loaded nickel foam. The overpotentials of the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites are 129, 92, and 189 mV (current density 10 mA cm-2), respectively. To investigate the HER kinetics of the electrocatalysts, the Tafel slope tests were evaluated through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). As shown in b, the 25, 50, and 100 wt % composites showed Tafel slopes of 118.6, 92.1, and 119.7 mV dec-1, respectively. These values are higher than that of Pt/C (34 mV dec-1) but lower than that of NF (161.7 mV dec-1). These steps are as follows: (1) The Volmer step, i.e., the electrochemical adsorption of hydrogen intermediates (Had) on the surface of the catalysts: H2O + e- + Medges 0 → Hads@Medges 0 + OH-. The structure of this MOF has channels with encapsulated POMs, which constitute rich active sites for the electrochemical HER. metadata.title:
Synthesis
of a Polyoxometalate-Encapsulated Metal–Organic
Framework via
In Situ Ligand Transformation
Showing Highly Catalytic Activity in Both Hydrogen Evolution and Dye
Degradation
